content.description: Start on crumbly rock and delicately move into fun face climbing with good pockets to a big rest ledge.  Finish through some overhangs to anchors.  Bring mid-size to small gear for the first 30 ft (I used a red tricam, a #1 BD cam and a 0.5 BD cam).
content.protection: Bolts start 30 ft up, then fixed anchors.
content.location: Bushwhack a bit uphill from the main trail after Eddie's 10b Roof.  If you see Franklinstein you've gone too far.

content.description: RC.com says 5.7, but I don't think so at all. This is 5.8 if you stay direct and don't wander right of the boltline to get up and right of the 3rd bolt. A decent line with a solid crux around the 3rd bolt leads to easier climbing afterwards. Start on some good face holds to a blank section that will keep you on your toes. Then a casual stroll on lower quality rock to the anchors.
content.location: Located just right of Raised by Sasquatch at the Contact Zone. This up the hill and right of the first routes encountered from the parking lot.

content.description: Climb dusty and crumbly rock up a chimney to the third bolt.  Watch out for a loose flake on the right wall.  Continue up the face on great rock, using good crimps to the crux below the small roof.  After the crux, pull the easier roof to the anchors.  This route shares a couple holds with Dynosaurus, but could share several holds if you stay farther to the right on the low-to-mid face.
content.location: Franklin Contact Zone--the next cliff face up the trail from the parking lot wall.  On the front face of the first prominent buttress in the Contact Zone, between two arete climbs, Potential Energy to climber's left and Dynosaurus to climber's right.

content.description: Climb the upstream face just right of the Dynosaurus arete through the roof and into the dihedral above.  Holds through the first couple bolts can be dirty.  The face has easier climbing and leads to the crux at the roof.  Once in the dihedral, the climbing is easy, though a little run-out to the anchors.
content.location: Franklin's Contact Zone - up the trail from the Parking Lot a few hundred feet.  Route is just right of the Dynosaurus arete on an upstream facing face.

content.description: This route makes a nice warm up for others in the area.   Climb up the face to the first bolt using really positive pockets and jugs.  After clipping the bolt, make a reachy move using some smaller crimps to eventually reach another bomber jug (crux).  Pull the small overhang and clip the shuts.
content.location: As you head right along the trail from the parking area toward the Contact Zone area, you will find a spur from the trail that switchbacks to the left and leads directly to this route.   It's located about 25 yds before you reach the Contact Zone.

content.description: A pretty good and very popular 10b.
content.location: At the top of the approach trail from the parking area you encounter a buttress. This is on the left face of the buttress. Route is to the right closest to the arete. Barney Rubble is to the left. the two routes share anchors.

content.description: A great climb.  Almost all on limestone and great technical movement with good holds where you need them.
content.location: From the top of the approach trail go right past the first major buttress a hundred yds or so to where the trail comes in close to the cliff again.  This is the bolted route you literally stand in the trail to belay.  It trends up and right.

content.description: Starts 5 ft left of Lost Planet Airmen, with camouflaged opening moves on mottled green/brown/white rock, then continue into small slopers and side pulls.  Angle right and finish through a fun roof to anchors shared with Lost Planet Airmen.
content.location: Right of a broken chimney and left of Lost Planet Airmen

content.description: Climb crumbly rock to the second bolt and surmount the ledge.  Clip the 3rd bolt, climb through the crux to a positive hold, and clip the 4th bolt--beware of hitting the ledge if you fall between bolts 3 and 4.  Climb easier rock to the anchor, with a short runout after the 5th bolt.
content.location: Franklin Contact Zone:  Just Right of the first buttress (containing Potential Energy and Dynosaurus) you encounter in the Contact Zone.  The route is on the river-facing wall heading up and right of the large roof above the dihedral.

content.description: Easy buckets take you to a high first bolt.  The second bolt is placed far off the line; bring an extendable draw our unclip it after making the next clip.  Between the second and third bolt is a large ledge.  After the ledge climb a series of overhangs with good rests in between.
Start on a high ledge.  Climb a short dihedral to the roof and continue on jugs, with a couple long reaches, to the anchors.
content.location: Franklin Contact Zone: Almost the end of the contact zone, where the trail begins separating from the cliff.  Around the corner to the Right, from Aloha and Break the Chain.  From the high ledge, Eddie's 10b Roof is on the right and A Moment of Clarity is on the left.

content.description: This is a very striking looking line!  When you see it, you'll want to climb it!   Start in the corner on a platform about 6 ft above the trail.  Reach left, clip the first bolt, and traverse left on to the arete.  Climb up the overhanging arete using very positive holds until you can gain a stance on the right of the arete.  (no hands rest here).   Once you shake out, head up left to find some small holds on the left side of the arete and climb straight up to reach the roof (crux).  From here, pull the roof, find the jugs, and continue to the top.   This is a pretty good first 5.12a for someone breaking into the grade as the crux is brief, and you get an amazing rest before it.   Super fun!!
content.location: This route climbs the overhanging arete on the right side of the first major formation in the Contact Zone area.   It's located about 15 yds to the right of Potential Energy.

content.description: This route is fairly sustained for the grade.   The crux is the lower half before you reach the overhang.   Climb straight up the face using many sloping holds and crimps.   Once you reach the overhang, the route eases up quite a bit.  From the overhang, follow some dirty jugs to reach the shuts.   The bolts on this route are spaced out a bit more than others in the area, very safe, but spaced a little further than most other routes in this area.
content.location: This route is the next line of bolts to the right of the open book (Aloha) in the Contact Zone area.

content.description:
One of my favorite routes at "Cranklin" with unique(for the area) sequency  limestone climbing down low and jugs up high if you can hang on long enough.

Well worth doing but be aware that the grade it the "given" grade and anyone who has climbed it I know of will say its the most sandbagged route at the crag.  Well worth doing but bring a bail biner if you are a 10a climber.  Prefferably a nice wiregate...
content.location: Just around the corner right of Lost Planet Airman in a small alcove-like area.  It ascends the center of the smooth wall on the left with a line of bolts up it.

content.description: Start is the same as Potential Energy.  At the first bolt, head up and left to reach a flake.  Careful on the flake, there's a loose block there.   From here, climb straight up to reach a set of amazingly good horizontal pockets below a blank section of face.   Figure out a way to reach the next positive hold (crux).  From here it's fairly easy going to the top, traverse right to reach the anchors above Potential Energy.
content.location: This is the first route of the Contact Zone Area proper that you will encounter as you walk in on the trail.  It's the left line of bolts through the center of the clean white face, just to the left of the Potential Energy arete.

content.description: A unique and fun diehedral-like climb with a fun roof finish.  Lots of bolts and a good lead for a budding leader or as a warmup for the routes nearby.
content.location: The diehedral to the right of Bircham's Beach.

content.description: Start on the high ledge just left of Eddie's 10b Roof.  Climb the face through the crux to the roof and short right-facing dihedral.  Turn the dihedral and roof, and finish on easier climbing to the anchors.
content.protection: 5 bolts and anchors (fixed carabiners on anchors).
content.location: Franklin's Contact Zone - Up the trail from the parking lot for a few hundred feet.  Almost to the end of the Contact Zone: right of Break the Chain, and left of Eddie's 10b Roof.
